trans-unit.source: A trigger action that begins a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard"></xref> and distributes its animations to their targeted objects and properties.

Use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> action with an <xref:System.Windows.EventTrigger> or a <xref:System.Windows.Trigger> to apply animations to their target properties and start them.

<xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> begins a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> by calling <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard.Begin%2A> on its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> reference when triggered.

When you begin a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> on a property that is already being animated by another <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard>, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.HandoffBehavior%2A> property of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> determines how the animation proceeds.
Pause, Resume, Stop, or Otherwise Control a Storyboard Interactively

To be able to pause, resume, or otherwise control a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Storyboard%2A> that was declared in markup interactively, you must set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Name%2A> property of its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard>.

You can then control the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> by using a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ControllableStoryboardAction> object (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.PauseStoryboard>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ResumeStoryboard>, or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.StopStoryboard>) to control it by referencing its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Name%2A>.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Name%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> is unspecified, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Storyboard%2A> cannot be interactively controlled after it is begun.

See [How to: Use Event Triggers to Control a Storyboard After It Starts](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/how-to-use-event-triggers-to-control-a-storyboard-after-it-starts.md) for more information.

In code, you may use the interactive methods of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> class to control a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> that was applied using a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard>.

As is the case when using <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ControllableStoryboardAction> objects, you must give the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> a name for its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> to be interactively controllable.
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref> class.
Gets or sets the proper hand-off behavior to start an animation clock in this storyboard
Using the Compose HandoffBehavior

When you apply a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationTimeline>, or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock> to a property by using <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.HandoffBehavior?displayProperty=fullName>, any <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock> objects previously associated with that property continue to consume system resources; the timing system does not remove these clocks automatically.

To avoid performance issues when you apply a large number of clocks using <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.HandoffBehavior.Compose>, you should remove composing clocks from the animated property after they complete.
There are several ways to remove a clock:

To remove all clocks from a property, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Animatable.ApplyAnimationClock%28System.Windows.DependencyProperty%2CSystem.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock%29> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Animatable.BeginAnimation%28System.Windows.DependencyProperty%2CSystem.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationTimeline%29> method of the animated object.
Specify the property being animated as the first parameter, and `null` as the second.
This will remove all animation clocks from the property.

To remove a specific <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock> from a list of clocks, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Controller%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.AnimationClock> to retrieve a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController>, then call the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController.Remove%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController>.
This is typically done in the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Completed> event handler for a clock.

Note that only root clocks can be controlled by a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController>; the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Controller%2A> property of a child clock returns `null`.
Note also that the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Clock.Completed> event is not called if the effective duration of the clock is forever.
In that case, the user must determine when to call <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ClockController.Remove%2A>.
This is primarily an issue for animations on objects that have a long lifetime.
When an object is garbage collected, its clocks are also disconnected and garbage collected.
For more information about clock objects, see [Animation and Timing System Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/animation-and-timing-system-overview.md).
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.HandoffBehavior"></xref> enumeration values.
The default value is <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.HandoffBehavior.SnapshotAndReplace"></xref>.
Gets or sets the name of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref> object.
By naming the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref> object, the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard"></xref> can be controlled after it is started.

To be able to pause, resume, or otherwise interactively control a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard>, set the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Name%2A> property of its <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> and use a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ControllableStoryboardAction> object like <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.PauseStoryboard>, <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.ResumeStoryboard>, or <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.StopStoryboard> to reference this name.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Name%2A> of <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard> is unspecified, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> cannot be interactively affected after it is begun; furthermore, when the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard> ends or enters its Fill period, the animation clocks are disposed of.

See [How to: Use Event Triggers to Control a Storyboard After It Starts](~/docs/framework/wpf/graphics-multimedia/how-to-use-event-triggers-to-control-a-storyboard-after-it-starts.md) for more information.
The name of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref>.
The default is `null`.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard"></xref> that this <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref> starts.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.Storyboard"></xref> that the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard"></xref> starts.
The default is `null`.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.BeginStoryboard.Storyboard"></xref> dependency property.
